The federal government should treat two consenting adults fairly, same-sex or otherwise. My opposition to this bill stems from the fundamental need for stronger protections for religious Americans so that the rights of all individuals acting in good-faith are protected equally.

Americans with deeply held religious beliefs and faith-based organizations deserve legal certainty, and this bill fell short of providing them that. Free speech and the right to practice one‚Äôs faith are fundamental rights guaranteed by the First Amendment.

Same-sex marriages sanctioned by the state should be recognized by the government and duly protected. But the private right of action included in this legislation is overly broad and could be abused by trial attorneys to target those with deeply held religious beliefs.

Every marriage entered into between two consenting adults deserves to be honored, respected, and protected. Unfortunately, while today's bill sought to codify aspects of the Obergefell decision, it failed to include sufficiently explicit religious liberty protections.üßµ
